text:
See, this is what we need more today in games.
I'm not saying games today are bad (Nintendo is still good) but the soundtracks aren't original. They're either stock music or music from pre-existing artists. Castlevania, Mega Man, and Final Fantasy (original 10) will always be the gods of gaming soundtracks, and more games nowadays need to learn from them.
author: Ethan Fung

text:
@Professor Mercury >The soundstracks aren't original.>and more games nowadays need to learn from them.
You're kinda contradicting yourself there, m8. But I get your point :)
author: Archonious

text: @Mattis Olstad Just because he said learn from them doesn't mean that it can't be original... You learn something -> You try to use that knowledge to make something original of your own -> You learn from them =/= unoriginal
author: EternallyLost

text: @Professor Mercury Love him, or hate him, Sonic still has some really great sound tracks.
author: Omar

text: Games back then didn't have the budget for elaborate pieces, so they had to use jingles that they could loop multiple times. Some pieces from games these days are really quite memorable and good. Modern Warfare 2 had great orchestral pieces by Hans Zimmer, and I think Mario Galaxy had a good combination of memorable tunes and orchestral quality. Don't let your nostalgia cloud your judgment.
author: Melodius

text: Man I got to play Castlevania. I always here about it being one of the best games. Yes I have heard of it since I was a kid in the 80's and 90's. My best friend was a huge fan while my fave game during that time was Mega Man. I still consider Mega Man the most epic of soundtracks in Video game history. And I'm not considering popularity or if people have heared it as a factor.::Yes Super Mario::¬†prob takes that poll.¬†But Mega Man gets up pumped, psyched, sing along, and make you¬†want to kick ass and still sounds memorable.¬†And I'm reassured its the best cause of all the games I would play as a kid in any system, I still remember my mom in the distance say "I like that song that's playing" while she cleaner or cooked or did whatever, she always had her two cents when a MM tune came on and she don't know jack about videogames or their names.
author: evilspin

text: @Professor Mercury I agree wholeheartedly. Most games nowadays use the same bland generic orchestra and techno music. Not that there's anything wrong with those musical genres. But that's ALL we ever use today! There seriously needs to exist more variety!

text: @Professor Mercury I agree wholeheartedly. Most games nowadays use the same bland generic orchestra and techno music. Not that there's anything wrong with those musical genres. But that's ALL we ever use today! There seriously needs to exist more variety!

text: @Wenceslao Futanaki¬†Music that can be heard in a movie can still be considered video game music. For example; look at games like Super Mario Galaxy one and two. text: But that's the thing: it's hard to be a gamer that prefers the underrated titles, like Super Paper Mario, Mega Man 5-8, Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask and Metroid: Other M over the critically acclaimed ones, like Sonic Adventure 2 and Super Smash Bros. Melee. It's hard to see your preferred games get so much hate for changing up things. And it's not pleasant in the slightest to be hated because you're not a fan of a particular game, like OoT. That's why I want the nostalgia effect to die.

text:
It's true that when you beat a game that lacks e.g. the ability to save and continue, the rush you get is entirely different from beating...well, any game where you basically are guaranteed to succeed eventually.

Like, when I first played through Battletoads, the high I got was incomparable to pretty much anything I've felt finishing any games since around the SNES era where I stopped buying consoles. Multiplayer games have their own allure but they definitely don't offer that experience.

text:
Don't get me wrong. I love RPG's and a game like FFVII (which is a little old by now) needs save points, etc. But the idea of "game over" has disappeared, in a way, and stopped making sense.

Longer games are not better games. I honestly think that Passwords were a more accurate device. The problem is that it easier to design a long, long game with no "re-playability" factor, than a short game which makes you play it again and again.

You can finish TMNT the arcade game in less than 15 minutes.
author: mantisdamospena

text: I think i understand what happens. Many old-school players feel that much of the challenge/reward factor, and challenge in general, has been lost on modern games, due to the absence of things such as Lives, Continues and Game Overs. These things however were only ever originally put in place to either make more money(in arcades) or to prolong the game experience. I believe there is no era that is 'better', and that every era has an equal amount of games i would consider among the 'greatest'.

text: I think there was a creativity, even a greatness in old games that's lacking nowadays. Game companies seemed more willing to and invest in good ideas back then. Today they are less motivated to do so because, from a business perspective, they make money off of graphics and gameplay aspects of a game rather than memorable ideas. However, Max Payne is also a great game.  It has one of the best stories out there.  But I must admit that I think there are more treasures in the old games than the new.

author: Bernabe De La Cruz

text:
@TheDudeYouHateToMeet  

Right on!  MM 4 is my favorite.  I love Dr. Cossack's castle themes.  Excluding MM1, all of the original 6 are really good games, but I certainly wouldn't put 2 over any of the other ones.  People just obsess over the goddamn metal blade and a few of the games standout tracks.

MM1 = has it's flaws, like wildly varying difficulty.
MM2 = improvement over 1 overall but with some gameplay kinks yet to be worked out.
MM3 - 6 = Hell yes.  And standardized boss health.
author: CloudyNumberOne

text:
This is the most overrated song of all time, from the most overrated game of all time. Why do people love MM2 so fucking much?! There are much better Mega Man games out there. 3, 4, and 5 are a million times better.
Maybe it's because I never had this one when I was a kid, so I'm not looking at it through rose coloured glasses.
Plus, it's way too easy for a Mega Man game. Even on "hard" mode, it's still a lot easier than any of the other Mega Man games on the NES.

text: The song is oddly appropriate for the stage in the sense that hey, if I just picked off all 8 robot masters, i'd be pretty fired up to finish the job too. text: @Ciferz = MM2 is the *simplest* of the series, I'll grant you that. But it's tremendously HARD to play well. Factors include Wood Man (dodging Leaf Shield is still one of the things that gets me), Air Man, Quick Man (spazziest, most undodgable boss ever, -and- his level of Force Beam doom), and the Wily Machine with the undodgable bouncy-beam. Crash Man's level can be really hard too, for those who don't know how to manipulate Pipis, and RSJ is by far the toughest "Big Eye" incarnate of the set.

text: @Mespritroth And yeah, that's the annoying part, really. It's mostly just a bandwagon thing. Everyone in the Okkusenman video comments is saying how sad it is, or how it made them cry. And like you admitted, you don't understand what it all means, so I'm willing to bet this is the case with most of them, too. So yeah, if you don't fully understand what something means and you're pretending to relate to it, that's poseur. If it's Japanese, then that's weeaboo :P
author: phubans

text: @Mespritroth Erm, it's not letting me post my reply. I'm just saying, I really appreciate and relate to a lot of stuff from Japan, too, but I don't like the way that some kids in America express that. They get obsessed and start going out of their way to pretend they're Japanese. It's really annoying. I feel like I can relate to Japan because I've been under their influence for over 20 years, so it's really annoying to see these kids who watch anime once and decide they're in touch with Japan.
author: phubans

text: @Mespritroth Erm, yeah... That's the thing that's annoying about it. Everyone is saying it's such a sad song, or it made them cry, etc... But they really don't know what it all means, so they're only pretending to relate to it since that's what everyone else is doing... And since it's Japanese and most of the kids pretending to relate are just white American kids, that's what makes it weeaboo shit XD

author: fuuka

text:
No idea where my original comment went...oh well.

When did I say the NES was what I started with? My first system was the 5200, but we won't get into that too much.

Why do you keep going on about nostalgia?  Because I said I liked a game when I was younger?  The reason why a game like SMB3 was a great game because it actually WAS and still IS a great game.  Depth, challenge, reflexes, and reward.  Developers try to find that balance to this day.  That's not nostalgia, those are simple facts.
author: RuleSeventySix

text:
...

That's what nostalgia is!

You think that "they were simply great games" because they were at a young age and that's what you started with.


And by the way dude. My first console was the NES, me and my friend ( and a very spoiled friend ) had A LOT of their games and we'd always play them. It may not have been long, but I did.

Overall the NES's library just sucked.

I usually do a Top 20 Musical scores from Scores, and I can't even think of a single NES RPG to pick.
author: Romalian

text:
You really don't see the correlation between age? If you're 22, then you were born right when the NES was coming out. meaning the first system you put your hands on was most likely a SNES. It has absolutely nothing to do with nostalgia.  They were simply great games played at a young age. 

Let's be real, if you know absolutely nothing about games and are gonna choose a game, chances are someone is gonna be drawn to the look of Devil May Cry 4 over Super Mario All Stars

Agree to disagree? :)
author: RuleSeventySix

text:
What does my age have anything to do with it unless Nostalgia has something to do with what you think the best console is? Nostalgia should have nothing to do with anything. It should be a matter of... if I know absolutely nothing about games and want to choose which console/games to start with... which would it be?

I suppose I shouldnt use the word 'era' then, since it could confuse and be misunderstood as back in 1990 the console sucked.
author: Romalian

text:
A few I enjoyed growing up: Bionic Commando, Super Mario 3, TMNT1/2, Metroid, Mike Tyson's Punch Out, Excitebike, Ice Climber, Megaman, Ninja Gaiden, Dr. Mario, Castlevania, Double Dragon 1/2.  There were some pretty awful games too, but any real gamer overlooking the NES era is nuts. Coincidence that you think SNES was the best era and your profile says you're 22? Nah :)

I noticed you have Final Fantasy listed  as one of your favorite games.  Which system do you think the whole series started?
author: RuleSeventySix

text:
Uh, to be honest with you. I think the NES era sucked.

SNES was by far the best era, then PSX, THEN NES ( by a very long distance though ).

Thinking on it, NES had hardly any good games, and with so many companies with little to no editing staff, you got rehashed games designed to take advantage of the consumer. It's pitiful.

text: Because it takes the typical 30 second awesome 8-bit video game theme and manages to stretch all the way past the minute mark. If you look at almost all NES 8-bit tunes, most of them repeat before they hit 30-45 seconds in length. Combine its length with the fact that it's genuinely an amazing progression of notes, and you have yourself one of the most awesome sounding tunes ever put forth by an 8-bit machine.

text: Yeah, this song does a superb job of truly making you feel like you're storming Skull Castle.  You're fighting your way into a technological fortress, the last bastion of a world-conquering madman with a genius at mechanized mayhem.  If you fail...the world is his.  That's what good final stage songs are supposed to do, and arguably, none does it better than this.
